question_text: A 33-year-old woman is evaluated for the sudden appearance of a rapidly expanding, painful skin lesion on her leg. She had a miscarriage 1 year ago. The activated partial thromboplastin time is prolonged.The skin lesion is shown.
question_stem: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
critique: The most likely diagnosis is antiphospholipid antibody syndrome (APLAS) (Option A), an autoimmune disorder in which thrombosis and fetal demise (in pregnancy) may occur. This patient's large area of jaggedly branching, angulated retiform purpura is a manifestation of intravascular clot formation in the small vessels of the skin, leading to overlying skin necrosis. Angulated retiform purpura can be the presenting manifestation of APLAS. A further clue to the presence of APLAS is prolongation of the activated partial thromboplastin time, as seen with this patient.
